course.subject: COMP
course.name: Machine Learning
course.description: Fundamentals of machine learning. Concept learning. Evaluating hypotheses. Supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning. Bayesian learning. Ensemble Methods. Deep learning.
course.prerequisites: (COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H) AND (ELEC 2600 OR IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19) OR IEDA 2520 OR IEDA 2540 OR ISOM 2500 OR LIFS 3150 OR MATH 2411 OR MATH 2421 OR MATH 2431)
course.exclusions: COMP 4331, COMP 5212, ISOM 3360

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Worst Course Experience
reviews.comment_content:
1. Overview

This is an introductory course on machine learning. In short, you will build models that learn useful patterns from features in dataset.

Teaching Syllabus:
- Artificial neural networks (Perceptron, deep networks, CNN, RNN, GAN)
- K-means Clustering
- PCA (short)
- Q Learning

TL;DR In case you don't have the time to read this 3400+ words review, just remember one thing: Don't register the course when James is teaching.


2. Coverage

If you have taken COMP 4471, congratz! You won't be able to learn anything from the course. The course content is basically a subset of COMP 4471 with a short intro to k-means clustering and PCA.

There are also some common stuffs in a standard ML course that is not covered.
- Regularization Techniques (e.g. dropout, weight decay, ...)
- Model Selection (e.g. bias-variance tradeoff, error metrics)
- Hyperparameter Tuning

Although the content suggested by the other review may be too difficult/theoretical, it would be good to add things like deep Q network or ensembling. Introducing some of the state-of-the-art research also would make the course more interesting.


3. Content Difficulty

The funny thing is although COMP 4471 covered more topics than this course, it covered them in more details. Even in COMP 1942, for the k-mean clustering and the PCA, it covered them step-by-step instead of going through them briefly.

As mentioned in other comments, COMP 4211 do not feel like a 4000-level course. It would be nice to go into more details in some of the parts. For example, it is interesting to see a sketch proof of perceptron convergence theorem (which I did in COMP 4901K).


4. Usefulness

The lectures covered basic concepts of machine learning but it is far enough from a real life machine learning project. It would only be useful if you want to take more machine learning courses in the future. But why bother registering this if you can learn everything from other courses.

Clustering, PCA - In COMP 1942
Q-Learning, RL - In COMP 3211
Perceptron, Deep Learning - In COMP 4901K

The machine learning research field is very active. However, there is minimal discussion on state-of-the-art techniques. Better to take COMP 4471 for that.

If you want to learn the basics on deep learning, take the course by Andrew Ng in coursera (like everyone suggested in the Reddit). You will benefit far more than taking this course.


5. Disconnection between Lectures & Assignments

To be honest, the project would have been a good project if the instruction was clear and the techniques used were introduced in the lecture. It is a good learning experience to implement a fast R-CNN from scratch (with PyTorch). However, this is only possible given the following:
- I took the coursera Deep Learning and Tensorflow in practice specialization beforehand.
- I had some (but not a lot) experience tuning hyperparamenters from the COMP 4901K project.
- I got a decent computer at home (i5-4460+GTX960, not too powerful but suffice).

The lecture does not cover any of the following:
- hyperparameter tuning (how to tune? what to tune? techniques?)
- debugging deep models (gradient checking? try a small dataset? visualization?)
- potential issues and their solution (vanishing/exploding gradient, dying ReLU)
- dealing with large datasets (how to scale up? baselines?)

How are we suppose to complete the project without learning anything above? Also, it would be much better if some object detection concepts (e.g. object proposal) are covered in the lecture.

P.S. I was taking COMP 3211, COMP 4421, COMP 4901K in the same semester. I did not take other machine learning related course (including COMP 4471) in any semesters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. Okay

Sorry this is quite personal. Okay. James really like to put 'Okay' in each of his sentence. Although it didn't affect the teaching quality, okay, too much, it is quite annoying to hear his voice, okay. If you like statistics, okay, he said 394 'okay's out of 591 sentences in a single lecture (from zoom transcript, Nov 19).


2. Course Management

The TAs are NOT HELPFUL AT ALL. The project instructions contains misleading extra information and contradictory statements. When you ask them for clarification, they like to rephrase the question and treat it as the answer. Most of the email I sent is CCed to the professor but he seems to not care about the poor replies at all.


3. Teaching Quality

Back to the professor. You might argue that he teaches okay. That's true. He did try to cover the notes clearly with examples which is better that some slides-reading professor in the department. The problem is he teaches too slowly so only basic content is covered. It would be very boring for those who have some background knowledge.

(Note: I usually spent time on preparation for each course before the course start. But even I have some background, most of the courses don't feel bored to me and I did gain quite a lot of insights from different courses.)


4. Classroom Interaction & Atmosphere

As the professor likes to see bored faces, there is a 10% participation component in the grading which requires everyone to turn on their webcam during lecture. It seems to me most of the students are doing their own stuff and the remaining are bored faces.

He did try to setup some polls and ask us to type something in chat from time to time. This, however, has nothing to do with the webcam. Why not find webcam videos and play them during lecture? You can even find those videos that keep nodding too. It would be better to see people nodding instead of bored faces.


5. Presentation Sections

The professor used four full lectures for student's presentation. If you don't want to teach, at least give us some more materials to read. Don't leave the course with untied ends. We don't even know how to tune a model!


6. What I have really learned... (Updated: Jan 13 2021)

Some words about my feeling. Sorry for those who cannot read chinese (cantonese).

如果你未睇曬個review 請你skip咗呢part睇埋落去先再返轉頭睇 🙏🏻

reviews.comment_grading:
0. Preface

Please leave me a message if you find a course that has worse grading than this one. I will go say sorry to James.


1. Grading Distribution

I think I don't need to say anything about how bullshit is this grading distribution. The numbers speak for themselves. Highest score in group project + full points everything else (98.2% overall) => A. Do you think 96.2% a good score? It is an A-. :D

My score and statistics:
Assignment 1 (10%): 10/10 (Mean: 9.3)
Assignment 2 (10%): 9/10 (Mean: 6.9)
Assignment 3 (10%): 10/10 (Mean: 8.1)
Mini Project (20%): 20/20 (Mean: 17)
Final Project (40%): 95.5/100 (Mean: 65.3)
Participation (10%): 3/3 (Mean: 2.6)
Overall: 97.2% => A
(Statistics from Canvas, other stats such as SD are not released)
(Note: 95.5 is the highest group score for the project mentioned by the TA in email)

Groupmate 1:
Assignments, Mini-project & Participation: 60/60
Final Project: 95.5/100
Overall: 98.2% => A

Groupmate 2:
Assignments, Mini-project & Participation: 58/60
Final Project: 95.5/100
Overall: 96.2% => A-

A friend from another group:
Assignments, Mini-project & Participation: 57/60
Final Project: 83/100
Overall: 90.2% => B+

More from this goop thread: https://hk.goop.ai/topic/ImuK/James-kwok-%E5%A5%BD%E7%88%9Bgrade

Hall of Poor Grades:
85 B-
86 B
87.5 B
89 B
89.74 B+
90.2 B+
90.5 B+
92 B+
92.24 B+
96 A-
96.2 A-
96.5 A-
97 A
97.2 A
98.2 A
(From PMs and goop)


2. Effort Required to Achieve the Grade

Please refer to the workload section. Want bad grades? Want stress? Good. Take this course. Work on the course materials full time and get a nice letter A.


3. Grading Transparency

There is no information regarding to the final project grading, which takes up 40% of the whole course. We have zero idea on how it is graded. The TAs try to avoid answering anything related to the grading (refer to attachments). Is it really true that we need a perfect score to get an A+? No one will ever know.


4. Contribution Scheme (Updated: Jan 5 2021)

From the new information that we have collected, we found there is a project score adjustment for groups that have unfair contributions. The formula is

individual score = min(100, group score * (self contribution/expected contribution))

The problem lies in a person can get a score much higher than the group score if the contribution is very unfair. This situation is not hypothetical. There is a 4-person group that has the following result:

Member A: Contribution 38.04% Personal project score 100
Member B: Contribution 22.57% Personal project score 76.84
Member C/D omitted as it is not important to the calculation
Group Project Score: 76.84 / 90.29% = 85.1
(Names are anonymous for privacy reason)

With some simple calculations, we can find Member A can get 129.49 points in the project if there is no cap (maximum of 100 score) applied! With such formula, Member A still get 100 points when their group project score is lowered to 65.72!

So, what went wrong? (in case you are still not convinced that there is a problem)

a) The effort and the score that can be obtained is NOT a linear relationship. For example, if you choose proj1, you can easily get >60 score by spending three or four hours modifying a pretrained convnet without much tuning. (I received a PM saying he soloed proj1 in one day and get 70+.) However, if you aim for the 80~90 range, you must spend quite a few days tuning the model or implement a much complicated model (proj2).

b) Groups with less than 4 person are severely penalized. According to the formula, for a 3 person group, each member are expected to take up 33.33% work each instead of 25% work. Our group was a 4 person group but one of our members dropped the course (smart choice!) so it becomes three. We pretty much have to do 25.0%/3=8.33% extra work without any rewards. Not to mention the results of our project would be much better if there is a fourth member helping us.

c) It is impossible to get a group score of 100. There is a peer review component and it is impossible to get everyone to give you full points. As a member of the highest scored group, I would say it is impossible to get a significantly better result given the short time period.

Do you understand what's the problem now? Ironically, the professor seems to be confused (or didn't even care/read) after we sent a long explanation to him (at least 4x longer than above). Refer to attachment for evidence.


5. Grade Review (Updated: Jan 24 2021)

We have sent two separate grade review requests regrading the grading:
a) the unfair contribution scheme (as mentioned above, refer to workload section [5] for details)
b) groups that have student(s) dropping out of the course are expected to contribute more (not calculated as freeriders but less members)

In short (more on workload section [5]), the grade review request is partially success and all members in my group have 1 subgrade up. We didn't find anyone else having their grades updated (plz let me know if you do).

Updated grades:
Myself (97.2%): A => A+
Groupmate 1 (98.2%): A => A+
Groupmate 2 (96.2%): A- => A
We failed to find other student who have their grade updated.

Although our group had our grades updated, I think this is still far from ideal. I apologize to those who have helped us fighting back the grades. We failed to get you all having a fair grade which I feel bad. I don't feel happy at all getting back the A+. To be honest, I don't really care if I do not get back the grade (that subgrade won't pull me up a lot anyway). We filed the request because the scheme is unfair - everyone should be assessed in a fair way. Most importantly, we want that stupid stubborn James to know HE IS WRONG.

I will keep the grading as "E" due to the following:

a) The scheme is still not transparent. We don't know how the revamped scheme work. I only received an email saying my final grade is updated to A+. I didn't receive other information regarding the appeal result.

b) The grading cutoff is still high. My teammate who got 96.2% total still results in an A. One may say there are courses with similar cutoff. However, the points can be easily deducted due to careless mistakes in assignments. I got 1% of course grade (10% of an assignment) deducted due to a single line of function call missing.

c) It is still unfair. It is understandable that it is not desirable to update the grades of everyone (especially those who may get their grades down). Despite that, there are much more thing that James and the TAs can do. A mass email explaining the situation to everyone? A less strict cutoff to balance the problem of the scheme? James did NONE of the these. He didn't even bother to solve anything before the department told him to.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Demanding Final Project & HW

The final project (topic 2) is an object detection system with Fast R-CNN. We have to follow the Fast R-CNN paper (with some modifications) to implement a turbulence detection system. The main overheads are the following:
- We have zero idea of Fast R-CNN before the project (so we need to read the papers)
- The instructions are vague, ambiguous and sometimes contradictory
- Object Proposal generation is time-consuming
- We don't have enough manpower and CPU/GPU power to debug everything

We spent at least 6 days full-time working on the project. Two or three days are even in the exam period! We would consider ourselves as some of the top students in the CS department (at least in terms of GPA). Even we put so much effort in the project, we did not manage to get a good result. Anyway, it is the best among all groups. I feel so tired and stressed out for the project. I don't wanna touch it anymore.

I will post the link to our project repo and powerpoint after obtaining permission from my groupmates.

The HW is also quite long if you do try to spend time tuning the hyperparameters. However, the effort seems not to be credited as the final performance is not calculated in the marking scheme. (although it is mentioned in the instructions the performance will be considered)


2. Deadlines on Unusual Days

The deadline of the final project is the last day of the exam period (22nd Dec). Glad that the final of my last subject is on 17th Dec so I can spend a few days full-time on the project. It would have been okay if the project had been released early. Sadly, it is released in late November so you have to deal with a shit heavy workload project alongside with your exam and end-of-semester work.


3. Required Attendance

Attend the lecture or lose 10%. And that 10% difference will probably cost you a nice letter grade. :) The prof/TA didn't mention how the attendance is calculated so you are forced to attend every lecture to prevent point deduction. Combined with the fact that the lecture is boring and without verbal interactions, it feels quite tiring to attend all the lectures.

The craziest thing is the professor move the last 4 lectures (presentation sections) to Dec 24 (Christmas Eve). Attendance is compulsory and we have a peer review form to fill in. That means, we have to listen to presentations of the same two topic for 5 hours and grade each of them. Great Christmas gift! Thank you professor!


4. Writing Follow-up Emails

I don't want to count how many emails that we have sent to the TAs/professor. Sometimes, they like holding emails. Sometimes, they like to rephrase our questions and treat that as an answer. We got to a point that feeling sending emails asking for clarifications won't help at all. So, we implemented some parts of our project not following the exact instructions to make it work (or work better).


5. Writing Grade Review Email (Updated: Jan 24 2021)

We have sent a grade review request email to the department due to the unfair grading scheme of the project (refer to Grading section for details). It took us almost 5 days to collect data, drafting the email, asking people to sign, etc. To be honest, I feel so exhausted that I still have to deal with this fu*king course after the end of semester.

Link to email:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/118up9RW5ZoThLqWPuZkfD0XWIGr9Fq1UQjJRM3av8q8/edit?usp=sharing
(Names are removed for privacy reason)

Previously, we put our contact method in this review for fellow victims to provide statistics, and sign the letter if they want. I would like to say a big THANK YOU to those who have provided statistics to us, especially those who have helped us signing the email. We finally manage to have 9 fellow students (out of 78) signing the email.

To start off, we got a bullshit response by James. The department simply forward our email to James, and ask him to respond to the points. Let me translate his response: "I think my scheme is good. You dumb as*es won't get your grades changed too much even if I change the scheme anyway." Attached is his reply (Warning: Please take care of your mental health. Seek help if needed). We filed another request for the issue that our teammate dropping out of the course after the group formation deadline. And, we got an even more ridiculous response from James (He said we should hire another freerider for better grades WTF). No other response from the department.

I was fu*king hopeless at that point. It was going to end horribly. There were argues among our group. My groupmate even sent a not-so-polite email to ask the department for a fair judgement (which I can't completely agree). Clearly, James is a very clever "old seafood" (slang in Cantonese, meaning who have lots of experience in the workplace).

The department responded us that they has just started conducting initial investigation. They said it was hard to get James' response. lol The department called a meeting (without James) to listen to our POV & evidence. Then, there were no news ... until I found my grade updated in SIS a week after.

We didn't really receive any official response from the department/James for the grade review request. The result is far from ideal and far from what we have expected (refer to grading section [5]). Sorry again for those who are still getting a bad grade. I don't have the energy to follow up this bullshit... I need some rest (and time to do my FYP. Sorry Desmond! :C)


6. It was just a Blackhole (Updated: Jan 13 2021)

All in all, this course was a fu*king blackhole. You put in effort, you got back nothing. You want grades? Don't put in efforts. Don't try to make sound argument with James. Pray to god gifting you a freerider in your group (which can easily pull your grades to 100) was enough.

I gave up my exam revision time. I gave up my Christmas Eve holiday. I gave up time doing my FYP. I gave up my sleeping time. The time that I spent in this course was way more than I did in COMP 2012H (which is famous for high workload). And... sigh... I don't know what to say anymore.


7. Writing Course Review (Updated: Jan 9 2021)

I spent a lot of time writing this review. Please share it with your friends so there will be less people suffering from this kind of bullshxt. If you did take the course with us or COMP 4331 this semester, you can help by giving (anonymous) feedback to the university.

http://qa.ust.hk/student_feedback.html

Lastly, I would like to thank each of you who had helped to upvote and share the review. Without your help, we would not be able to find fellow victims to provide statistics. And, this review would not have been that impactful.

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Writing this review for DY and a standard COMP4211 offering
reviews.comment_content:
Key note: This is one of the few "decentralised" course in the CSE department, meaning that different professors are likely to include different teaching materials and grading schemes. Your content will depend on which professor you register in, and this is one thing I dislike about.

However, talking about DY, his lectures are well-structured with fruitful, complete, and up-to-date content.

01 Introduction
02 Linear Regression
03 Logistic Regression
04 Feedforward Neural Networks
05 Deep Neural Networks
06 Convolution Neural Networks
07 Recurrent Neural Networks
08 Principal Component Analysis
09 Auto-encoders
10 Clustering
11 Support Vector Machines
12 Decision Tree and Random Forests
13 Reinforcement Learning

As you can see, almost every cutting-edge topic in Supervised Learning, Unsupervised Learning, and Reinforcement Learning are covered. I would want it to include one lecture on Recommender Systems and Naive Bayes Models though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kindly note that this review is writing for Professor YEUNG, Dit-Yan only. If the current semester offering is taught by another professor, such as James Kwok, please refer to other reviews about him.

Professor DY Yeung is the department head of CSE. He teaches perfectly good with good presentation and no accent. He can explain every single concept well, encourage students' participation and to communicate effectively with students and the TA.

He manages time well, starts and ends each lesson on-time, cover all scheduled materials just-in-time, and release PAs and collect them at reasonable pace that can work as a consolidation on lecture materials.

In conclusion, he is one of the best instructors in HKUST.
reviews.comment_grading:
This grading scheme was for an online semester. No exam was scheduled for my semester.  It is not likely to happen for a F2F semester, so please reference to other threads if needed.

PA1 10% - Multi-layer Perceptrons (MLP) on some toy datasets
PA2 15% - Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) on image classifier
PA3 15% - Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) on fake news text detector

Zoom Poll 10% - Each lecture one or two poll(s), half point for incorrect, full point for correct, no point for missed poll

Project 1 30% - Work on one of the topics as asked (Not a "freewill" project). Download the dataset on your own and do whatever models you like. Make a report and video present afterwards. (Group of 2)

Project 2 20% - Extended learning. On your own, read papers on one of the topics asked  (again, not totally free choice), then film a 30-mins youtube video and teach your fellow students on the advanced topic. Video links are released to the rest of the class after the end of semester. (Single-person project)


Grading is fairly good.
My grade:
PA1: 100/100
PA2: 94/100
PA3: 98/100
Project 1: 96/100 (Mean 82.7, sd 17.8)
Project 2: 94/100 (Mean 88.6, sd 18.3)
Polling: About 85% in total (Mean about 77%)

I am not sure about the mean of each PAs, but guess around 90 for PA1 and 80ish for PAs2/3.

For the group project, you need to fill in a peer contribution table at the end of the report where it may adjust your individual score from the group score. However, I am not sure how it actually works coz my group just peacefully wrote 50:50 among me and my partner.

My Final Letter Grade: A

Fair grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workloads are fine for the PAs, which have 2-3 weeks to complete for each. However, note that no skeleton codes are provided and you need to start everything from scratch starting from packages installing and importing. Some labs may be useful for references though.

Each PA took me around two full days to work on the codes and an extra  day for writing up report. If you aim for perfection, make sure to do each step carefully and write your report clearly according to the guidelines. Minor typo in the code may make huge difference or even a complete wrong in your final submission. Start early because random bugs are likely and training time can be long for ML assignments.

The workloads suddenly increased steeply towards the end of the semester, where we have our Project 1 due in week 12 and Project 2 due in week 13. These two projects take some times in report writing and making powerpoint slides for filming the video if you aim for excellence. For me, I worked overnight for two days to complete Project 1.

You will get two NQA coupons (i.e. late days) for the whole semester where you can use on any assignment or project.

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.title: An incomplete machine learning course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction (e.g. feature extraction, supervised vs unsupervised learning, multi-class learning)

2. Linear Support vector machine (SVM)

3. nonlinear SVM (kernel)

4. overfitting (cross validation)

5. perceptron (AND/OR/XOR)

6. Adaptive linear element (adaline)
[HIGHLIGHT: stochastic gradient descent]

7. hidden units (nonlinear RBF, sigmoid unit, ReLU)

8. back-propagation

9. convolutional neural network (CNN, LeNet)

10. introduction to Reinforcement learning (Markov decision process)

11. policy and policy evaluation

12. policy iteration, value iteration

13. Q learning

14. generalization and function approximation

The rating is given as the content is hard. Please do not underestimate its difficulty. You may not easily build AlphaGo in a course just like Rome wasn't built in a day.

A lot more basic machine learning (ML) concepts, such as regularization, regression, rule-based learning/classification, Naive Bayes classification, kNN, k-means & hierarchical clustering, decision tree, random forest, hidden Markov model are not covered in this course because several lessons are cancelled. It is quite a pity that genetic algorithms, recurrent neural network (RNN) and LSTM are not included here.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is solemn in the class (although sometimes he makes fun in the class). The explanation is clear but he avoids answering questions that are not covered in the course materials. By the way, the PDF slides are quite old-fashioned. Do not skip classes if you have no understanding on machine learning before.
reviews.comment_grading: Actually the grading distribution is not quite clear and the statistics are not announced explicitly. The means are ~70s in midterm and final exams. I think the grading is fair and acceptable. For me, each of the three assignments do not attain full marks and I get below mean in midterm and final exams but luckily I get B grade at the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Since Theano is used for implementation and the assignments are renovated, there is no 'source' useful and the questions become more challenging and you have to really spend time on thinking how to solve the problems. If you are not that smart (and I am not that smart :P) and you want to get good grade in COMP elective courses, I suggest you find other courses to take and self-study machine learning. I take this course and spend much effort on it because I think I will not have time to really study hard in ML/AI MOOCs and I want to force myself to learn ML (as I believe this time I did not learn ML I would have to learn it in the future at a more 'painful' cost when staying in IT-related industries or computer science postgraduate studies).

[2018/05/28]Luckily the course materials have been revised to include Tensorflow now...

reviews.author: SamF
reviews.title: Do NOT take this course
reviews.comment_content:
Same as the title: Do NOT take this course
The reasons have been mentioned in another review "Worst Course Experience" for 2020-21 Fall.
I totally agree with that review. This course is very shit!!!

The content is too introductory as a 4000 level course. Watching Youtube videos can learn more than taking this course.
FYI: (credit to that review)
- Artificial neural networks (Perceptron, deep networks, CNN, RNN, GAN)
- K-means Clustering
- PCA (short)
- Q Learning

If you want to take this course, I strongly suggest you avoid Kowk, James Tin Yau.
There are some courses like COMP4471 and COMP4901K, which also teach machine learning and they are more useful. And you can take MATH4432 as well.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not really so bad because of my low expectation for HKUST teaching quality.

Professor spoke too slowly although his explanation was quite clear in lectures. For every lecture, I just switched on my camera but did not connect to the audio. I just watched Youtube videos or 1.5x the speed of the lecture videos.

For tutorials, the materials were good which gave you hints for mini project and assignments. TA also covered Python coding.

I would really appreciate they could cover more advanced topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lack of Transparency:
You can only find the mean in Canvas. No other statistics for all of the assignment and project.

!!!!!!
I only know the grading scheme of the project until other students asking for grading. The professor had never mentioned it wither on course webpage or Canvas. If I had known this fking grading scheme, I would have never chosen this course.
!!!!!!

Mean from Canvas:
Ass 1 (10%): 9.3/10
Ass 2 (10%): 6.9/10
Ass 3 (10%): 8.1/10
Mini individual project (20%): 17/20
Group project (40%): 65.3/100
Parti (10%): 2.6/3

The mean final score should be around 76.09. If you get 85, you can only get B-. There are so many problems with the grading scheme, details please refer to the review "Worst Course Experience".

Finally:
Think twice before taking this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload mainly came from the group project, which lacked clear instructions (in my opinion). Just remember to spend enough time on training your model, then it will be fine.

reviews.author: The_Unknown
reviews.title: My future is doomed
reviews.comment_content: Standard stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say average. It was pretty hard following lectures in the early semester. But over time, slowly adapted to it.
reviews.comment_grading:
I thought B would be my worst grade at UST since only LANG 4030 and fyp would be left after this semester.
Well, I was wrong.
Now, C+ is my worst grade. :)

The saddest thing is that the grading system isn't even all that bad compared to previous semesters. I got quite a few marks below mean in finals (50% weightage), full marks in assignment (30% weightage) and 88 in midterms (20% weightage), so I got C+.
This is technically a good/average grade given the enormous weightage of finals (hence my labeling of grading as B).
But the small class (58 students) disturbed the overall mean, making it pretty darn high. It felt difficult... at least for me.
That said, the exam structure was pretty garbage though. Most questions were related to computation and math.
Here is the thing. I am bad at Maths and slow at dry runs.
I mean, scatter Matrix? I don't have the faintest recollection of what that is. Been 2-3 yrs since a math class.
Probability? My nightmare.
Computations? Time. Need time T_T
ML concepts? Wait, yeah forgot this was ML exam
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low workload this semester. The lowest among all the COMP courses I have taken till now.
Only three assignments with answers pretty much present in tutorials.

reviews.author: Dok
reviews.comment_content:
SVM
- Linear
- Nonlinear
- Overfitting

Artificial Neural Networks
- Perceptrons
- Adaline
- Hidden units
- Backpropagation
- Computational graph
- Image processing
- CNN

Reinforcement Learning
- Policy Iteration, Value iteration
- Q learning
- Generalisation and function approximation

Unsupervised learning
- k-means clustering
- GAN
- Principal component analysis
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor teaches clearly, but lecture slides are very bad. I highly suggest going to the lectures otherwise you won't be able to understand anything by just reading the slides. The lecture itself has no coding, and is all mathematics and theory. Kinda boring sometimes, to be honest. 9AM didn't help either. But the pace is quite slow, so as long as you attend the lectures it will be fine. All the coding is done in the tutorials in Python and Tensorflow by the TAs.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Assignments = 25%
Midterm = 25%
Final = 50%

Got above mean for all assignments, 1sd for both midterm and final, but gave me a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Each assignment is 2~3 questions, some maths and some coding. Maths part is the same as what the professor does during lectures. Coding can be quite annoying, especially when training takes literally hours.

Studying for the exams were very annoying because the lecture slides are very bad and the professor does not provide any past papers, review notes, or practice questions. Exam questions have 0 coding and all maths/theory/drawing neural nets etc. Mostly some variation of the green "example" slides, so quite easy. Midterm was 1 hour long and Final was 3 hours long but most people left before the time was up.

reviews.author: CW
reviews.title: Not recommended (at least when James is teaching)
reviews.comment_content:
In short: This course should be renamed "SVM and a little bit of some other stuff" and made into a 2000-level course.

The course description mentioned much more content, but here are what were actually teached:
- SVM
- Neural network
- Reinforcement learning
- K-means clustering
AND THAT'S ALL.

Only SVM is taught with a 4000-level difficultly and depth.
Neural network: Perceptrons, adaline, deeper network and computational graph, CNN. These are fine. Questions like "how to combat overfitting", "why CNN over fully connected" are not answered.
RL: Policy/value iteration + Q learning.

There are SO MANY THINGS that I can think of and worth teaching in a 4000-level ML course: VC theorem, PCA, actor-critic, Boltzmann machine, etc.

My suggestion: Cut the CNN part and leave it for 4901J. Teach faster, please. You are teaching year 3/4 CS students, not kindergarten kids.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture: Teaches very slowly with unnecessarily and sometimes stupid questions. I think the instructor tries to make the class more active but honestly he is wasting too much time on that. Didn't go after midterm.

Lecture notes: Unstructured and over-simplified. Might be usable in a classroom interaction setting but putting more details definitely helps with revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 assignments (25%)
Midterm (25%)
Final examination (50%)

Grade is not out yet.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy. Assignments are unnecessarily complicated on non-important parts. Final exam is ridiculous.

Assignment 2/3: No skeleton code. Wasting time to build structure of loading data, training network and validation instead of the actual algorithm.

Exam: Full of numerical calculation. More than half of the questions are basically "dry run this algorithm and write all intermediate steps".
Another question is "here is a neural network with weird kernel size, padding and stride, compute its output size at every layer" and there are 6 layers. Part b: Now some those kernel size, padding and stride are changed. Do the exact same thing again.
There is more. Question: Draw the computational graph. Little did I know, he expected a graph with ~30 nodes with detail for every single multiplication and addition.

The exam is designed for a computer, not a human. Questions related to ML concepts accounts for I think ~10% of the total marks. Ridiculous.

reviews.author: lanbo
reviews.title: Do not take Kwok's 4211
reviews.comment_content: If you want to learn some machine learning stuff, take any other courses that have mentioned ml. In Kwok's 4211, you will only understand MLP.
reviews.comment_teaching: I'm not sure if he knew he is teaching a 4000 level course. He spent serval weeks teaching perception and MLP. And for supervised learning, unsupervised learning, his teaching is just like "oh this is XXX, the concept is XXX, let's see some simplest example. DONE".
reviews.comment_grading:
I can only say the grading for homework and mini-project, which have correct answers is OK. But for the final project, just pray.
The most unbelievable one is the participation. I joined most of the courses but he gave me 0, 0% out of 10% total grade. And when I tried to contact him, he just disappeared.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework is easy, and you do not need to write too much code. The only part that takes time is waiting for your computer to train the model.

reviews.author: Jeh
reviews.comment_content:
Covered topics from easy to advanced
Assignment + exam + project
No attendance taken
Supervised learning, unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning... etc
reviews.comment_teaching:
Explains concept clearly.
Will prove step by step.
Not only reading PowerPoint.
Good English.
Enthusiastic towards teaching.
Require self learning of coding in order to finish the coding assignments
reviews.comment_grading:
Exam is more to test understanding on concepts rather than math/coding.
Not hard to get high marks in exam/assignments/projects.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly assignments/coding. Workload is quite heavy but he reduced workload on demand.
Project has limited guidance but provide a lot of freedom on selecting topics.

reviews.author: Roger LIIIN
reviews.comment_content:
- Perceptron, deep networks, CNN, RNN, GAN
- K-means Clustering
- PCA
- Q Learning
reviews.comment_teaching:
Well, the professor is quite informative on some of the basic knowledge in the lecture slide and the examples. But it is said that the information is quite introductory. You can find much useful information on the internet and Youtube.
For the teaching style, the professor talks quite slowly, and as many reviews have pointed out, he focuses on explaining the easy parts rather than the difficult parts in the lecture. Also, I personally feel like he doesn't like to answers students' questions. Most of the time when there are questions raised in class, he will just ask everyone in the class to help answer the questions without directly answering them.
reviews.comment_grading: According to the professor, this semester is the first semester they switch to project-based mode. However, because of this, the grading scheme becomes very unclear. As some of the course reviews have pointed out, you can only find the mean of each assignment on Canva. Also, sometimes the TA will grade your work wrongly. So you have to be very careful about your final grade and try to attend the appealing session if possible.
reviews.comment_workload:
We have 3 coding assignments, 1 individual mini-project, and one final project. For the final project, we have a presentation.
If I really have to say, the final project is quite challenging, not just about the content (some of the instructions are quite unclear and lack explanations). The format of the presentation is also quite unclear (the content, the format, that every member should participate in the presentation, etc. many information are not informed.). Furthermore, the overall grading scheme of the final is quite unclear too. (I guess the professor just grades your total contribution mainly based on your contribution to the presentation. I have friends who were not informed to participate in the final presentation got a really bad grade in the final project.)

reviews.author: mattwinand
reviews.title: Good Instructor, Bad TAs
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm:

SVM: Linear and non-linear, overfitting
Artifical Neural Network (Half)
- Perceptron
- Adaline
- Hiden Units
- Backpropagation
- Computational graph

After Midterm
Articial Neural Network (the rest)
- Image and CNN

Reinforcement Learning
- Policy and value iteration
- Q learning
- Function Approximation

Below were not covered in the final
Unsupervised learning
- k-means custering
- Generative Adversarial Networks
reviews.comment_teaching:
James is an excellent professor, detailed explanation, unfortunately, only half people attended the class which is very depressed to him. You have to attend the class, otherwise, you may not be able to understand the notes.

But the TAs are not that helpful, the tutorials are totally wasting time, the TAs won't return the answer for the assignments. Suppose tutorial provides you the practical example(s) helping you to understand the lecture notes, unfortunately, each topic only has one example.

The lecture teaches you a very general concept, and tutorial teaches you how to use Tensorflow to implement it, some sample codes were provided, but you may need to do some researches about the assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
assignments 25%
midterm 25%
final 50%

Midterm mean: 58/100, sd 25
Final mean: 43/100, sd 20
mean is C+ to B- range
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low workload, 3 assignments,
first: SVM
second: ANN and CNN
third: Policy and value iteration

if you simply refer to (copy) the tutorial codes, you will get 80% marks.

No past paper, no assignment answers, no examples, then no workload for the midterm and final.

reviews.author: gary_ho122
reviews.title: Great course for people who want to minor in big data and comp student
reviews.comment_content:
Here is the course content:
SVM, kernel, cross validation and some Q learning. The content is quite interesting if you are interested in machine learning. Also, if you are a non-cs student, it is easy to learn too.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching process is fun. The professor know how to interact with the student and the lesson are quite useful. He can explain the things quite clearly and the concept is not hard to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is much better than the other course in the computer science department. I score around mean then already have B+.Very good grade
reviews.comment_workload: Only have midterm and assignment. The workload for assignment is very low. You can find the algo from online and can easily answer the question and gain full marks.

reviews.author: petch
reviews.comment_content: The content is very interesting. The class mainly focused on supervised learning and unsupervised learning. But, the content will focus on supervised learning more than unsupervised learning. The topic is very useful.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is very good. The professor is very active and make the content very interesting. He shows us interesting slides and good representation for machine learning. Highly recommend this class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair. Mainly focused on midterm and final exams. Not much assignments and class participations.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much. Acceptable. You have time to review the lecture.

reviews.author: kla
reviews.title: DY is good
reviews.comment_content:
Linear Regression
Logistic Regression
Neural Networks
CNN
RNN
Autoencoders
Clustering
SVM
Decision Tree
Reinforcement Learning
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good teaching. DY speaks fluent english and covers all lecture contents smoothly.

He is the department head and definitely totally different from James Kwok.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading, not very good, not very bad. I guess it is straightly following the UST grading guidelines.

10%, 15%, 15% PA1, PA2, PA3
30%, 20% Project 1, Project 2
10% In-class Zoom Polling.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 PAs which are heavy in workloads
Two projects which are even more heavy.

PA3, Project 1 and Project 2 due almost without a break. When you finish a PA, then you need to work on the next successively.

reviews.author: cshime
reviews.title: DY = fair grading
reviews.comment_content:
Fruitful content.

The course taught from supervised learning to semi-supervised learning, finally end with reinforcement learning. Actually DY touched also some point on unsupervised learning, by taking this course, for sure you will gain some useful concepts towards machine learning.

Topics include:
1. Linear Regression
2. Logistic Regression
3. Feedforward Neural Network
4. Deep Neural Network
5. CNN
6. RNN
7. Component Analysis
8. Auto encoders
9. Clustering
10. SVM
11. Decision Tree
12. Reinforcement Learning
reviews.comment_teaching:
I skipped lots of lesson because of the high workload this semester.

However, I could say that, from the lesson I have attended this semester, DY taught clearly.

The lecture notes are well written. Also, recordings are complete (Although this semester should be very complete due to zoom system lol).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. Maybe due to DY is the head of the department, he tend to give grade by following normal standard.

For me, I could say, I really calculated the mean stats and my overall marks, after than I compared two marks to see how I differ from mean score.

My overall percentage is somehow 82.1x% and mean percentage is 82.0x%. Mean score brought me a B grade. Therefore I think that is a fair grading.

One more thing: The marking standard is very transparent. For each assessment, TA will give you feedback on each question and send you through email. It is sure that you can learn from your mistakes by reading the feedback.
reviews.comment_workload:
Despite there are just two assignments, one project and one take-home final exam in this semester, the assessments did take me a lot of time to complete.

For assignment 1, it is easy. However, assignment 2 did take me 3 weeks to complete it. This semester, assignment 2 requires student to implement a Multilabel Classifier CNN and a review classification RNN. While I searched the assignment 2 given last year, it only required a single-label CNN only. I am very sure the workload has been upgraded in this semester.

But to be fair, if you are prepared, the assignments should not be hard and should not take you lots of time.

reviews.author: tmnrb
reviews.title: COMP 4211 - Machine Learning
reviews.comment_content: The course is very complete with some videos to understand more the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is explaining in detail all the part of the course and is can explain very clearly some part if you have questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair but the TAs are a bit harsh on the assignment grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not very high.
3 assignments :
First one : 12%
Second Assignment : 18% (Harder than the first one)
One project : 30%. The project can be a Kaggle competition or you can choose a dataset and then do your own study on the dataset.

FInal exam : 40%

reviews.author: csisgood
reviews.title: Machine Learning + Deep Learning
reviews.comment_content:
Some points to conclude this course (TLDR):
1. Low Workloads
2. Rich Contents
3. Well Written Lecture Notes

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Rich Contents
The following topics are covered:
1. Machine Learning Introduction
2. Linear Regression
3. Logistic Regression
4. Feed forward Neural Networks
5. Deep Neural Networks
6. Convolutional Neural Networks
7. Recurrent Neural Networks
8. Principal Component Analysis
9. Auto encoders
10. Clustering
11. Support Vector Machines
12. Decision Trees and Random Forests
13. Reinforcement Learning
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor can clearly explain all parts in lecture notes.
The lecture notes are well written.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final 81, mean 66
Assignment and Project nearly full mark
=B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 3 things need to complete for this courses.

12% Assignment - 1 (Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, NN)
18% Assignment - 2 (De Noising Auto Encoder)
30% Project
40% Final Exam

For the project, you can either choose joining a Kaggle competition or use the dataset in Kaggle and propose your own topics.

For all the assignments and project, you need to hand in both the codes and report. And the project will be graded by the professor.

Assignments and Project are not difficult but need to be careful. TAs and Professor marks the assignments strictly.

reviews.author: Kinchen
reviews.title: Introduction to the world of Machine learning
reviews.comment_content:
When I took this course, the schedule is quite tight because some of the classes have to be cancelled due to holidays. The contents covered are as bellows.

1. Support vector machines
Linear SVM
Nonlinear SVM
overfitting
2. Artificial neural networks
perceptrons
adaline
MLP
hidden units
back-propagation
convolutional neural net
3. Unsupervised learning
clustering
principal component analysis
autoencoder
4. Reinforcement learning
policy
finding the optimal policy
policy iteration, value iteration
Q learning
generalization and function approximation
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly speaking, Prof. Kwok's teaching is quite clear and structured. He explained the concepts of the algorithm with some examples, which is helpful for us to make sense of them. Even if you get lost in the middle of the class, you could easily catch up with him.

However, the lecture notes he used are a bit vague. Sometimes you need to focus in class in order to understand what the slides mean. And some of the examples he used may appear in the exams. So stay focused in class especially he would be trying to use some examples to explain the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: Since it was a small class and the professor thinks everyone is doing great in the class, the grading is not bad when I took the course. I think the mean would be around B to B+.
reviews.comment_workload: In total, there are three assignments and if you really pay attention to the class, the assignments are not difficult. And the TAs are quite helpful and we could ask them if there is anything unclear or if we needed help.

reviews.author: Stephen
reviews.title: Not a course you would do for grade
reviews.comment_content: Basic Stuff. You can find syllabus elsewhere.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is detailed but might be a little bit slow.
reviews.comment_grading:
P1 Full, mean around 70ish, Graded by TA
P2 74, mean around 65ish, Graded by TA
P3 96 (with Kaggle Top 2%), mean around 89ish, Graded by Prof
Final 88, mean around 60 ish
Grade A- with ard 89-90% overall
From my friend, 92% overall should also be A-.

I guess there is a lot of competition in this course for top grades. Assignments are graded strictly based on accuracy of results. No or few partial scores are given. For exam, appeals are not usually useful. The final exam is mainly on conceptual questions which require some qualitative understandings of the subjects. Only easy quantitative questions.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is moderate. No attendance requirement. Attending the tutorials might be helpful for programming assignments.

reviews.author: ZacharyLau
reviews.comment_content: 雖然話包括 Supervised Learning, Unsupervised Learning 同Reinforcement Learning，時間關係好可能只講到 Supervised Learning 同 Reinforcement Learning 。
reviews.comment_teaching:
James 同TA 都好好人。上堂氣氛都輕鬆。
好難得係UST 到遇到咁好嘅prof. 同TA 。
reviews.comment_grading:
3 assignments 25%
mid-term 25%
final 50%

Grading 應該係reasonable，我自己分數較高，最後拎 A＋ 。
reviews.comment_workload: 只有 3份 assignments，難度唔大，只係要注意最後一份會比較遲出，係exam period 交。

reviews.author: Platano
reviews.title: Machine Learning
reviews.comment_content: This course mainly introduces some major issues and algorithms in the field of Machine Learning. It includes three parts: Supervised Learning, Unsupervised Learning, and Reinforcement Learning. Nevin is very clear in class and he is very patient. However, one of the characteristics of this course is that there are few exercises, so there may be situations where I feel that I have mastered a certain algorithm, but in fact there are still unclear details. It is recommended that after learning an algorithm, you can construct a scenario and practice it yourself, or simply implement it yourself to help you thoroughly understand it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher talked in great detail, more about formula derivation and content not available on the Internet.
The tone of the lecture is relatively calm and easy to get sleepy
reviews.comment_grading:
The score is normal and reasonable.
Assignments, project essays, and final exams will be checked, and the repetition rate cannot exceed 35%
reviews.comment_workload: There are a lot of homework, and I have to complete a project, as well as 4 homework (questioning) and 4 assignment (writing code), plus the final exam, the course pressure is still great.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: CBT
reviews.comment_content:
DY thinks every word that comes out of his mouth is gold, so you have to attend every single lecture and answer every IPRS correctly to get full participation.

DY thinks students are computers and should work like machines, so you get 0 marks for submitting assignments late.
reviews.comment_teaching: Too bad if you prefer watching recordings. You must come to the lecture or die.
reviews.comment_grading: Update later, but according to the prediction from my feedforward neural network, the grading should be wonderful.
reviews.comment_workload: Very fun assignments that take more than 12 hours to do (each).
